sweave2rmd 0.0.1

    contribute.Rmd

    Contribute

    There are many ways to contribute to our project.

    • Convert a Sweave document to Rmd
    • Reach out to maintainers to see if they’ll accept a pull request
    • Improve our documentation
    • Share our project via social media

    Convert a Sweave document to Rmd

    Before You Begin

    Good to Know
    • Required
      • git
      • feature request workflow
      • R
      • Rmarkdown,Rmarkdown book or Rstudio Rmarkdown cheatsheet
    • Familiarity with
      • Bioconductor
      • BiocStyle
    Good to Have
    • pandoc

    Claim a Vignette to Convert

    1. Check the Sweave2rmd Project Board
    2. Select an issue to work on by setting Status to Todo, Last Modified to today, and change Assigned to your GitHub username.
    3. If the package is not maintained by Bioconductor, you must contact the maintainer to verify they will accept a pull request with the converted vignette.

    Confirm Willingness of Maintainer to Accept Pull Request

    Contact the Maintainer via Email
    1. Search for the package on BiocViews.
    2. Click on the package name to go to the package’s landing page.
    3. Find the maintainer’s email.

    4. Email the maintainer asking if they would accept a pull request with the converted vignette. You can modify the following example email to send to the maintainer:

      Hi,

I'm volunteering with [Sweave2Rmd](https://github.com/Bioconductor/sweave2rmd)
and we're trying to convert all Bioconductor Sweave vignettes into `.Rmd`
files. Would you be willing to accept a pull request converting *vignette
name* for *package name* from one of our volunteers? We'll take care of
converting the file. We'll ask you to review and accept the pull request.
You'll also need to bump the version number in your DESCRIPTION file so that
the build machines will recognize that a new version is available.

Thanks for your time.
    5. On the project board, set the Status to Contacted and Last Modified to today
    6. If the maintainer will accept the pull request, set the Status to Maintainer Interested. If they will not accept a pull request, set it to Maintainer Not Interested. If after two weeks, the maintainer is not responsive, set the Status to Unresponsive.

    7. Set Last Modified to today.

    Convert the .Rnw vignette to .Rmd

    Note: We use file to indicate the name of the Sweave file that we will convert to .Rmd.

    1. On the project board, set the Status to In Progress.
    2. Search for the package on BiocViews.
    3. Click on the package to visit its landing page.
    4. Find the current Sweave file that you will convert. Use this to compare the with the .Rmd version you will create.
    5. Fork the repository you will work on.
    6. Clone your newly forked repository.
    7. Make a branch for your changes: git switch -c file-Rmd
    8. If you have pandoc, use it to preprocess. In the terminal
      1. cp file.Rnw file.tex
      2. pandoc -s file.tex -o file.md
      3. mv file.md file.Rmd
    9. If the file doesn’t have yaml at the top, add it using the following as an example:
    ---
title: "Vignette Title"
author: "Vignette Author"
package: PackageName
output: 
  BiocStyle::html_document
vignette: >
  %\VignetteIndexEntry{Vignette Title}
  %\VignetteEngine{knitr::rmarkdown}
  %\VignetteEncoding{UTF-8}  
---
    1. If BiocStyle isn’t in the DESCRIPTION file, add it under Suggests.`
    2. Convert any lines manually as necessary.
    3. If using Rstudio, Knit your new vignette and compare with the Sweave version.
    4. Repeat 10-12 until your new HTML vignettes accurately represents the Sweave version.
    5. Commit your changes with git commit -m 'Convert file to Rmd'.
    6. Remove the Sweave file with git rm file.Rnw
    7. Commit your change with git commit -m 'Remove file.Rnw'.
    8. Push your branch with git push origin file-rmd.
    9. On github.com, go to your forked repository and create a pull request.
    10. In the comments of the pull request, ask for a review with @Bioconductor/sweave2rmd and attach the HTML vignette.
    11. On the project board, set the Status to PR Made.
    12. If your reviewer leaves any comments, address them until your pull request is ready to merge.

    Review a Pull Request

    When reviewing a pull request, confirm

    • the HTML document is representative of the Sweave document
    • the .Rmd file is representative of the Sweave document
    • the .Rmd file uses best practices

    Use the comments to communicate issues to resolve for the volunteer who made the pull request.

    When all issues are resolved, ask the maintainer to approve the pull request and remind them to bump the version in the DESCRIPTION file.

    Contents

    Developed by J Wokaty.
